bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, April 10, 1926

div1.p: Carter thanks Russell for sending the letter quoting Dr. Andrew Balfour's reference to Henry Rose Carter and informs Russell that her editing work on the History of Yellow Fever is only in its preliminary stages.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, April 10, 1926
div1.opener:
-----------
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
April 10, 1926.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your letter of April 7th., containing
copy of a paragraph of Dr. Andrew Balfour's letter, of Delast October,
to Mr. Williamson, in which he makes reference to Father. It reached
me this morning and I know I need not tell you how greatly I prize it
both as an expression of Dr. Balfour's opinion and as another example of
your ever thoughtful kindness. What you people of The Foundation have
meant to me in the past long months no words can adequately express. A
letter from “61 Broadway,” is always, in a sense, “aa letter from home.”
so closely have the work and the workers been knit up with Father's and
my life and so beautifully have you remembered my continued interest in
and enthusiasm infor the work.

I hope I made it sufficiently clear, in my letter of March 31st.,
that in starting “preliminary work for continuing the History of Yellow
Fever.” I did not yet consider myself as actually at work on the book
itself, nor entitled, as yet, to be on the payroll. Of course, such
work is a necessary preliminary, but its alow and painful and I would
not feel justified so far in saying that I was “putting over,” a whole
time job.” However, things are clearing up. [unclear]

Once more thanking you for your letter and with very best
remembrances, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours. Laura A. Carter Dr. F. F. Russell,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Oh! Dr. Gordon Thomson motored over from Baltimore the other
day and we had a very pleasant time talking over “old times” in
Jamaica and his recent very pleasant glimpse of you all when he
landed in New York.
By the way, Dr. Balfour has sent me a reprint of his Presidential
Address on “Some British and American Pioneers in Tropical Medicine and
Hygiene,” which was most kind and thoughtful in him.
